title: 104_s1206
content: The "Adoption Assistance Act" is cited as the short title. It introduces a refundable credit for adoption expenses under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Adoption Assistance Act introduces a credit for qualified adoption expenses paid by individuals, limited to $5,000 per child. The Adoption Assistance Act introduces a credit for qualified adoption expenses paid by individuals, limited to $5,000 per child. The credit is determined based on the taxpayer's adjusted gross income exceeding $60,000, with no double benefit allowed for expenses eligible for deduction or credit under other tax provisions. The Adoption Assistance Act allows a credit for qualified adoption expenses, excluding expenses covered by other programs. Qualified adoption expenses include adoption fees, court costs, and attorney fees directly related to the adoption process. The Adoption Assistance Act allows a credit for qualified adoption expenses, excluding expenses covered by other programs. Qualified adoption expenses include adoption fees, court costs, and attorney fees directly related to the legal and final adoption of a child by the taxpayer, not incurred in violation of State or Federal law or in carrying out any surrogate parenting arrangement. The term 'qualified adoption expenses' does not include expenses in connection with the adoption of a spouse's child. Married couples must file joint returns. The text discusses amendments to section 1324(b) of title 31, United States Code, and the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Title II of the text addresses adoption assistance for federal employees, specifically reimbursement for adoption expenses under Subpart G of part III of title 5, United States Code. The effective date for the amendments made in this section is for taxable years beginning after December 31, 1995. Chapter 90 of the text discusses adoption benefits for federal employees, defining terms like 'agency' and 'employee' for this purpose. The term 'adoption expenses' under chapter 89 includes fees from adoption agencies, placement fees, legal fees, counseling fees, medical expenses, foster-care charges, and other necessary adoption-related costs. The head of each agency shall establish a program for reimbursing employees for adoption expenses incurred in adopting a child, including fees from adoption agencies, legal fees, counseling fees, medical expenses, foster-care charges, and transportation expenses. Reimbursement is provided after the adoption becomes final. The agency's program reimburses employees for adoption expenses, including fees from adoption agencies, legal fees, counseling fees, medical expenses, foster-care charges, and transportation expenses. Reimbursement is only available if the child is under 18 years old, unmarried, and if appropriate written application is filed within the required time frame. The agency's program reimburses employees for adoption expenses, including fees from adoption agencies, legal fees, counseling fees, medical expenses, foster-care charges, and transportation expenses. Reimbursement is available if the child is under 18 years old, unmarried, and if the appropriate written application is filed within the required time frame. The reimbursement amount for adoption expenses incurred cannot exceed $2,000 per adopting parent if both parents are eligible employees. No payment will be made if it would cause the total amount payable to the adoptive parents under this program, combined with any other program payments, to exceed a certain limit. The guidelines for adoption expense reimbursement include a limit of $4,000 and provisions for interagency cooperation. Reimbursement is paid from the appropriate fund, and marital status cannot be a basis for denial. The Office of Personnel Management has the authority to issue general guidelines. The Office of Personnel Management can issue guidelines to ensure consistent administration of adoption expense reimbursement. Executive agencies must follow these guidelines in their regulations. The Office can also provide assistance to agencies upon request. Conforming amendments are made to the heading of subpart G of title 5. The Office of Personnel Management can issue guidelines for adoption expense reimbursement. Executive agencies must comply with these guidelines. Amendments are made to subpart G of title 5, United States Code, regarding annuities, insurance, and miscellaneous benefits. Section 1005 of title 39, United States Code, is amended to apply Section 9001 of title 5 to the Postal Service. Regulations must be consistent with guidelines issued under subsection (g)(1) of such section. The effective date of this title is October 1, 1995, and applies to adoptions finalized on or after that date. Title III excludes adoption assistance. SEC. 301 amends the Internal Revenue Code to exclude adoption assistance, with an effective date of October 1, 1995, applying to adoptions finalized on or after that date. The Internal Revenue Code excludes employee adoption assistance benefits and military adoption assistance benefits from an employee's gross income with respect to the adoption of a child. Employee adoption assistance benefits refer to payments by an employer for qualified adoption expenses, while military adoption assistance benefits are also included. The terms 'employer' and 'employee' are defined in relation to section 127(c). Military adoption assistance benefits refer to benefits provided under specific sections of the United States Code. Qualified adoption expenses include necessary fees and costs directly related to the adoption process. The term 'eligible child' refers to an individual under 18 years old or someone with physical or mental disabilities, for whom the taxpayer incurs adoption expenses directly related to legal adoption and not in violation of any laws. The Secretary will issue regulations to coordinate this section with other provisions allowing credits or deductions for qualified adoption expenses. A clerical amendment will update the table of sections accordingly. Effective Date: The amendments made to this section will apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 1995.
